2 minute video review:
https://youtu.be/wJd5w1vzdvo

Cosmic Trip is a really immersive RTS game that implements VR controls really well.

You start out at your home base, and you begin harvesting crystals with your Worker Bot. Crystals are the main currency of the game.

After acquiring some resources, you build buildings, with which you can build an army of bots.
The goal is to build up your army of bots, and then find and destroy the alien heart. You can command your bots to do most of the attacking for you, but you also have weapons at your disposal so you can attack alongside them, or defend your base yourself if you’re running low on bots.

The game mechanics take some getting used to. Almost every aspect of the gameplay is a new way of playing a strategy game that I’ve never seen before. It’s nice that it’s refreshing, but give yourself time to figure it out, it’s worth the learning curve.

All of the interactions are very tactile. You physically push buttons, insert discs, and throw bots. It’s a very satisfying way to play with the motion controllers.

If you’re not in the mood for pure strategy, there’s also the Chill game mode which allows you to just play how you want and enjoy the scenery.

It’s a well polished game. The game performance is fast and responsive, and the visual style is pleasing and fun.

I received this for free to review. But for strategy fans, it’s absolutely worth the $20 price tag. It’s a strategy experience that you’ve never played before.

I meriti di Cosmic Trip sono molteplici.  In primo luogo, è un gioco davvero originale e di ardua collocazione, viene definito come uno strategico o come un tower defense, ma in realtà non assomiglia a nulla che abbia mai giocato con o senza realtà virtuale. In secondo luogo ha la migliore interfaccia utente mai vista, un capolavoro di immediatezza e utilizzabilità che - si spera - altri giochi VR possano copiare o quantomeno utilizzare come fonte di ispirazione. Infine, gli sviluppatori di Cosmic Trip hanno sicuramente fumato roba buona perché il titolo ha uno stile folle ed originale, con uno spiccato gusto anni sessanta misto a robotica emozionale e riferimenti "Pikminiani".

Andiamo con ordine. Cosmic Trip nasce ai primordi dell'epoca Vive come primo vero strategico ad usare in modo intensivo il roomscale, ovvero l'intero spazio fisico della stanza in cui ci si muove. La mappa prevede una serie di tappe interconnesse da portali, i quali vengono "tirati su" a mano come una serranda e oltrepassati come una porta. Non ha senso a parole, ma di persona una volta compreso il sistema funziona a meraviglia. In ogni tappa possono esserci risorse, che vanno estratte e lavorate, con una catena di tecnologie da costruire, ottenere e manutenere nienteaffatto modesta. Tutto qui ha una forte connotazione fisica, per esempio per costruire robot dovremo prima circondarci di una torre di costruzione, la quale va alimentata a batteria e programmata inserendo una cartuccia software, tutte cose che dovrete fare voi a mano.

Ad ostacolare il nostro lavoro ci saranno immancabili creature aliene, anche loro dedite all'espansione sul territorio, e poco amichevoli con noi o con le nostre costruzioni, specie se "stuzzicati" dal nostro desiderio di espansione. Tutto ciò che manovrerete sarà di colore bianco/arancio, rotondeggiante e "puffoso": è difficile non affezionarsi ai robot, che riconoscendoci salutano o ci svolazzano attorno con area interrogativa se mal indirizzati. Tutto gira a puntino, con ottime musiche e belle illustrazioni (colonna sonora e artbook sono acquistabili come DLC) senza il consueto retrogusto a basso budget tipico delle economiche produzioni VR.

L'unico vero difetto del gioco, se proprio ne si volesse trovare uno, è che nonostante le varie modalità di gioco non è nato ne' risulta organizzato in forma di campagna. Ovvero, manca una serie di livelli da superare in sequenza, le mappe disponibili potranno essere giocate più volte impostanto differenti parametri alla ricerca del miglior risultato (idealmente, di conquistare l'intero scenario) ma questo è quanto. Il gioco è uscito dallo stadio early access, e si vede, ma gli sviluppatori continuano a seguire il progetto quindi non escludo che una tale modalità possa essere un domani aggiunta.

A fronte di questo unico neo, e considerando il prezzo e la qualità offerta, Cosmic Trip è un gioco che difficilmente farete mancare nella vostra collezione.

One of the most polished VR games out there, made by a small indie studio! This is the first VR RTS I'm aware off and now it has finally launched out of early access into the full version. Roomscale strategy game at its finest.

(TL;DR conclusion at the bottom; Disclaimer: I got a free key from the developer to provide feedback before the full release, this may of course cause some unconscious bias which you should take into account)

[b]Visuals[/b]

Looking at the screenshots and watching the trailer should give you a great impression how it will look in-game. The visuals are phenomenal and not many VR games out there (especially indie VR games) have such a coherent art style, polished looks while having a very uniquely-appearing setting. The locales you can play in bombard you with variety, are playable at different times of the day to significantly alter the atmosphere and mood of the game. The bright, colorful visuals are a great fit for the currently available VR HMDs as the game thrives on delivering clean, but pleasant graphics.

Everything oozes with charm. From your own bots that are often very cutesy, to the enemies which have a distinct design which allows you to detect them from far away and judge which one and how many of them are approaching you.

A lot of care also went into the animations. Every building and every item is accompanied by small, but important animations that makes the world feel much more alive.

Another great selling point is the wonderfully crafted UI. I have never seen an UI as beautiful and as fitting as this one in a VR game. Pushing buttons, putting in batteries, scrolling through the map, everything works great and looks great as well.

[b]Sound[/b]

Another thing where Cosmic Trip excels. Fitting sound track, an abundance of SFX that accompany all of your actions. Again, this is another part where the game excels. One could criticize that during the more hectic moments filled with > 50 NPCs the sound mixing could be a bit better to put more emphasis on the more important and alarming sounds, however, this is just some small nit-picking for late game scenarios.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

In this game there are 3 game modes: chill (just relaxing, no stress game mode), strategy (the meat of the game) and wave mode. Chill mode wasn't really exciting (well, it shouldn't be due to its name) and not much to my interest. The other 2 modes, were great, though.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

In the strategy mode you can play on 3 maps where the objective is to find the 'heart' of the enemy base and destroy it. You have to gather resources (crystals and ectoplasm) to build more bots to either help you harvest the resources, defend your base or attack new places to take over. Over time, the enemy tries to do the same and they are building up their army as well as taking over new places.

Resources run out over time, forcing you to go to new 'nodes' to built up bases there and gather new resources. If you're not careful enough when expanding, the enemy could attack prior, defenseless bases and destroy valuable buildings.

Bots can be built with the resources and upgraded versions are also available. In the game there are 4 main bots: workers (gathering crystals with only little defense capability), battle bots (melee bots, the cheapest available), laser bots (ranged attack bots) and medics (healer bots and collecting ectoplasm).

Building wise there are helpful and often necessary structures that help with harvesting crystals, turrets to build, bot builders, bot 'servers' to expand the maximum of buildable bots, etc. Most buildings will cost more and more to prevent early snowballing.

You have a map available where you can command your bots to go to different places. The map is very intuitive and allows you to select only specific bots and a specific numbers of bots if you want to. You can also see if any enemies are approaching and you can plan ahead which nodes you want to tackle next.

You yourself as a player aren't defenseless either. You have a disc thrower for single-target damage, a bubble gun to build up temporary defenses and a shield. Your main 'omni-tool' is also a good way to dispatch enemies' buildings by literally 'pulling their plug'.

A great gameplay mode that can become addicting until you find out the right strategy to beat a certain map. I hope the developers consider adding more difficulties to increase the already excellent replayabiltiy even further.
